------=_NextPart_001_00B0_01C9F5BA.0E4561C0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Colin,

Actually, there is more to the story.  Indeed, I am using a highly =
distributed form of TWEANN based on NEAT run on hybrid, heterogeneous compu=
ter clusters.  I've been playing around with various parallelization scheme=
s, different data reduction schemes based on a wide variety of experiments =
and data. In order to do this both efficiently and effectively, and retain =
the mathematical graph structures, I went back to first principles and re-e=
ngineered the elemental hierarchy as shown in the Package Dependencies jpeg=
 attached. The MathLib has certain imports into the Graphs namespace (throu=
gh a GraphLib which is not shown to retain clarity).

Obviously, there is a=
 lot of detail missing, but the major insight I noticed was how information=
 in genomes and neural networks gets encoded in the graph structure. Unlike=
 a matrix, one cannot just look at a network structure and recognize the in=
formation, but very much like a CPPN, one can perturb the very compact stru=
cture through the interfaces (inputs) and get consistent patterned represen=
tations out.  This is a very efficient encoding mechanism, indeed.

Notice =
too that I have separated the concern of Entities, such as Individuals, Pop=
ulations and Species from their genomes.  This is somewhat similar to separ=
ating the location vertices (I'm using n-dim hyperpoints) from the nodes in=
 graphs.  Nodes can, and are, inherited to be neural network neurons, and c=
ombined with genetic information, to become genetically inspired artificial=
 neural networks.  Yet, the topological aspects are described at a very pri=
mitive level (the mathematical graph structure). I am experimenting with co=
-evolutions of higher level constructs GA's and TWEANNs and comparing them =
with low level mathematical graph constructs (representations).

Finally, I=
 have turned my HyperNEAT inspired TWEANN loose on the problem space of con=
figuring the hybrid, heterogeneous compute clusters in solving the dynamics=
 of partitioning the data and tasks given various contexts (schedules of ex=
periments, priorities, the existing configuration capabilities of the clust=
er hardware) to see if it can evolve better "compute fabrics" than I can ha=
rd-code using the parallel_for loops on the CPUs (used in distributing code=
 modules) and various CUDA structures on the GPUs.  That answers so far hav=
e been humbling.

Ken Lloyd


From: Colin Green 
Sent: Thursday, June 25, 2=
009 4:09 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: about the inn=
ovation number





Hi,

2009/6/25 Ken Lloyd <kalloyd@...>:
>
> Did=
 anyone else find it problematic that the NeuronGeneId was generated
> just=
 like the InnovationId for the ConnectionGene?

Not especially but I did de=
cide to use two separate incrementing
counters, one for neurons and one for=
 connections. The two types of
gene have their own 'ID' space. I think my m=
ain motivation was to
prevent the ID space from being exhausted - y'know if=
 some day this
becomes distributed neat and/or running on much faster hardw=
are and/or
for long timescales. I like to over engineer shall we say.

> In=
 my implementation, I
> decided to use a GUID for gene identification, and =
only use the innovation
> number for sequencing (aging) the connection gene=
s - substantially reducing
> the range of the innovation numbers.

Well, a =
GUID is 4 bytes which is a bit of overkill (a bit rich given
my previous se=
ntence :), also if you use standard approaches of
generating GUID's they wi=
ll have some problems.

1) Performance. GUIDs are typically a hash of hardw=
are IDs (network
card MAC and other things), current time, and any other so=
urce of
randomness such as a background service that measures the interval
=
between key presses. These all sap performance and can also result in
clust=
ers of very close GUIDs if you ask for a few (or many) in a short
time peri=
od (e.g. within a 50/th of a second).

2) The uses of hardware IDs also mea=
ns you probably are generating IDs
within a narrow sub-set of all possibke =
IDs - that is you get the
overhead of dealing with 4 bytes without the bene=
fits of more IDs.
This also means that GUID clashes might occur - an increm=
enting value
gives you efficient utilization of the availablke ID space.

O=
K on the other hand a GUID might be a good solution in a distributed
settin=
g - you can generate a GUID with practical zero chance of
clashing with GUI=
Ds generated on other machines. However you still
need a central register o=
f all IDs from all machines in order re-use
IDs correctly when adding new n=
odes and connections.

> The search space for identifying identical preexis=
ting connections is always
> problematic (due to the time penalty it impose=
s), even if done efficiently.
> How about a small static structure similar =
to a step function CPPN (ok, just
> an array, diagonalized of course) to ta=
ke the endpoints of connections as
> inputs and generate a value (1 or (tru=
e) =3D prior exists, 0 =3D it doesn't).
> Here, using the endpoint GUIDs ke=
eps the array small enough, only encoding
> surviving searchable neurons.

=
I /think/ you're effectively describing a hashmap that uses the
connection =
endpoints as a key and stores the connection ID as the
mapped value. This i=
s what sharpneat does, however I think the hashmap
is discarded after each =
generation (so we ensure ID use only within a
generation). Sharpneat 2 take=
s a more pragmatic approach of keeping a
permanent history of innovation ID=
s keyed by endpoints as before, but
the history length is limited (it's a h=
ybrid of a circular buffer and
a hashmap) so as to prevent it expanding ind=
efinitely and consuming
all memory and increasing lookup time.

BTW Coding =
on V2 will resume shortly - I've been busy with moving and
stuff the last f=
ew months. I've also been catching up on HyperNeat and
novelty search paper=
s, so hopefully this help me design the code to
assist in these research di=
rections.

Colin.
